body:
Thanks for the PR.

It would be easier to verify the change if the PR description included a bit more detail (e.g. why it's not OK to pass a `Serde` with `V1` instead of `V` to `groupBy`). This may be obvious to @guozhangwang, but it's generally a good idea to explain things for a wider audience.

Also, the PR description becomes the commit message so it's better to use a PR comment for things unrelated to the code (like mentioning reviewers).
Thanks @ijuma - i'll close and do it again
@guozhangwang
@dguy, thanks. Btw, you can simply edit the PR title and/or description in the future instead of creating a new one.
Thanks, the change itself looks good. Can you please update the PR description, it's outdated. Also, no reason to repeat the JIRA id in the description.

I should mention that we are not checking explicitly if `topics` in `subscribe` or `partitions` in `assign` are `null`. Should we? It's a bit odd that we check what's in the collection, but not the collection itself. Particularly as we are checking if `pattern` is `null`.
LGTM
LGTM, thanks @vahidhashemian for working through all the comments and improving docs on the existing tests!
@ewencp, seems like we should double-commit this to `0.10.0`. What do you think?

@ijuma I'm open to it, but skeptical -- would you consider this a critical fix that _must_ go into 0.10.0.1? It's an unfortunate misbehavior, but seems like an edge case I wouldn't consider critical. Updating regex subscriptions dynamically is not a particularly broad use case and this was only found through testing of a KIP as I understand it, not someone hitting a production issue with the new consumer.

All that said, if you want to cherry-pick, I will not object :)
@guozhangwang Thank you for your information.Probably I was confused because of title of issue. I made pull request with updated version.
jenkins : timeout error on Kstreams test not related to this PR.retest this please

Thank you @ijuma for your review.Updated.Please have a look.thanks.
jenkins : timeout error on Kstreams test not related to this PR.retest this please

@ewencp It's probably not critical, but it's a clear bug fix, it seemed low risk and it could surprise users in production. I wouldn't call an edge case because it's so easy to trigger (it's not like it requires a complex sequence of operations) even if it may be a bit rare in practice.

Do you agree that it's low risk? Happy to cherry-pick, if so. Otherwise, better to leave it indeed.

@ijuma Pushed to 0.10.0, and updated JIRA fix version. We should probably figure out how to distinguish between critical, low-risk, and not, but in this case, agreed I'm not too worried about existing functionality or compatibility.
Thanks!
@msiuts, can you please address Jun's review comments?

@glikson Merged to both trunk and 0.10.0. Thanks!

Also your github account only has the user id, and I managed to use your full name "Alex Glikson" in the commit log. Please let me know if you prefer "glikson" still.

There are a couple of other places where `StateSerdes.valueFrom` is called and we should consider checking for null values, for example:

1) `RocksDBStore` in line 255.
2) `InMemoryKeyValueLoggedStore` in line 69.

@dguy Good catch. But I am wondering what if users still want to retain the original key information in the grouped stream? With the current `KStream.groupBy` APIs the original key must be either included in the aggregate key, or it will be lost.

Checkstyle failure:

```
jdk7/streams/src/main/java/org/apache/kafka/streams/kstream/internals/AbstractStream.java:34:11: 'if' is not followed by whitespace.
[ant:checkstyle] /x1/jenkins/jenkins-slave/workspace/kafka-trunk-git-pr-jdk7/streams/src/main/java/org/apache/kafka/streams/kstream/internals/KStreamImpl.java:231:11: 'if' is not followed by whitespace.
 FAILED
```

LGTM overall.

Could you change your comment to have a more meaningful description since it will be included in the commit log?
Thanks, updated the name in the profile.

@guozhangwang if they want the original key they would use `KStream.groupByKey` this just converts the existing `KStream<K, V>` to a `KGroupedStream<K, V>` without out any key selection and re-partitioning.
@guozhangwang @mjsax
LGTM
@guozhangwang fixed checkstyle.

@ijuma Thank you for the reminder!

I improved the documentation of  truncateTo and explained why we should check channel.size and not original size. Are there any open questions/comments to address?

PlaintextConsumerTest.testPatternUnsubscription and PlaintextConsumerTest.testSubsequentPatternSubscription fail for me on commit 87b3ce with JDK 1.8.0_31. The failure messages are:

`java.lang.AssertionError: Expected partitions [topic-0, topic-1, tblablac-0, tblablac-1] but actually got []`
and

`java.lang.AssertionError: Expected partitions [topic-0, topic-1, foo-0] but actually got []`

All other test cases pass.
@guozhangwang Any input about `writeAsText` vs `print` ?

Passing in the `StateStoreSupplier` gives good flexibility, but i'm wondering if we should be able to override the default so we don't need to pass a `StateStoreSupplier` unless we wan't something different.

@dguy  Thanks for your comments. You mean, we shouldn't overload methods but have the ones with `StateStoreSupplier` argument. If user wants to use this property, she can provide with non-null parameter, otherwise, she will pass null for `StateStoreSupplier`. 
Please correct me if I am wrong.

@jeyhunkarimov no, sorry, that isn't what i meant. I think the overloaded methods are fine. It was more about what if i just want to use a `MyKVStateStore` for everything? It would be nice if we could set the default in config and then i could just use the methods without the `StateStoreSupplier`
@guozhangwang - any thoughts on this?

@dguy So, we can define globally `StateStoreSupplier`, if the method (ex. reduce) doesn't specify the `StateStoreSupplier`, by default global one is used. Otherwise, overloaded methods' non-null  `StateStoreSupplier`  argument always overrides the global one.
@jeyhunkarimov - i think globally we'd need to define a `StoreFactory` see `Stores.create`. Again, i'd like to get @guozhangwang's views on this
LGTM. Merged to trunk.

@dguy Actually I meant if users still want to choose a different group-by key, but want to maintain the original key in the value field so that they can be accessed still. With the current API the original key would either be dropped if a complete new group-by key is selected, or it must be embedded into the selected group-by key since the value field is not changed at all.

There is still work-around about this though, e.g. users could call `stream.map(/* duplicate the key as part of the value field*/).groupBy(/* choose a new key*/)`. So it maybe OK as well. Let's how common it is and if the workaround is satisfiable enough, and revisit this later.
LGTM and merged to trunk.
Is there any doc-related changes needed?
No changes to docs needed

@magnusr Looking at the recent failed builds it seems the issue is intermittent where one or more pattern subscription tests are failing, but there is no one test that always fail. I assume all tests pass locally for you?
Any ideas why this was closed? I assume I should make a new PR?
@alexlod, it was merged.
@guozhangwang Was auto-repartitioning merger to `0.10.x`, too? (ie, does this go to `0.10.x` as well?)
Oh... great! Thanks @ijuma, @granders, @ewencp for reviewing.
No it is not in 0.10.0, since it is API changes I kept it only for 0.10.1 (trunk).
Hi @jeyhunkarimov seems this PR is incorrectly rebased, do you want to continue working on the old PR addressing my comments?
I have seen this Jenkins failure quite a few times and have filed https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/KAFKA-3876 to track it separately.
LGTM. Merged to both trunk and 0.10.0.

@magnusr Yeah, would be good to know if this is consistent and only this test fails. Because we basically have system integration tests as unit tests, they end up causing transient failures. We've noticed some other tests failing under Jenkins and many seem to be relying on the default timeout from `TestUtils.waitUntilTrue`, so we may just need to increase that to make it more reliable across a variety of test hardware.
removed dupes

I think it does not hurt to still add the prefix as its parent stream name in `writeAsText`, although we let users to specify the file paths and in practice they may be different or maybe not. It's just like in our current log4j settings, where multiple classes could write to the same log file, but with different prefix still (as class names).
@vahidhashemian: This was a local run on my laptop. 804 test run, 2 tests failed. Only tried once, so I don't know if it's intermittent or not.
@guozhangwang I cannot make PR as I re-forked the repo and therefore it shows "from unknown repository". Should I make again rebased PR ?

I do not know why you need to re-fork, but normally you can create a local branch from your forked repo and use `git pull apache trunk` whenever necessary to get the latest commits in trunk into your working branch. With that you can just work on the same branch and update the same PR, i.e. https://github.com/apache/kafka/pull/1569, and it will not show as `unknown repository`.

Could you close the existing three PRs for the same JIRA ticket Kafka-3836 and retry the process I mentioned in #1569?
Thoughts @ewencp and @guozhangwang? You both independently mentioned that the 5 second timeout may be too low for Jenkins when it's under load.
I'm definitely in favor, and in fact I'd prefer to increase it to 30 seconds :)
@ijuma Yeah, this has come up across a few different tests, so seems reasonable. Should we fire off a few builds repeatedly on Confluent's and Apache's Jenkins to make sure the selected value works?
I go with @guozhangwang. I think when I was running with these failures I once tried a 10 second wait and it still failed one of the tests. So 30 secs might be a safer choice.

We are using 15 seconds as the default in `org.apache.kafka.test.TestUtils.waitForCondition`, so we could perhaps make them both 15.

I am a bit reluctant to increase the default timeout all the way to 30 seconds (6 times the original value). If there are tests that need that much, they can override the timeout perhaps?
Sounds good.
Sounds good to me too.

BTW we should really make a pass over our unit test suits and try to cleanup some cases that have overlapping functional coverages, especially in our integration test suits (5 bucks we can at least find 10 of them :P ).

@SinghAsDev, I checked with Jun and he's happy for this to go in as long as it's not too complicated. Perhaps the best thing is to first look at the SASL case to see how we handle that before spending effort on anything else?
@guozhangwang, yes, I definitely agree.
Fair enough, adding streamName parameter to `writeAsText` as well.

@mjsax @guozhangwang 

Updates per latest reviews, added overloaded methods for `writeAsText` to specify the stream name for labeling key/value pairs.  At this point I believe all review comments have been addressed.

Hello, @guozhangwang ,

May I ease the process of reviewing for you by any chance?

Updated the test to use the `waitForCondition` method to confirm that all added/removed topics are accounted for in the `StreamThread.createStreamTask` method call.  Previously, the test was only asserting that the `createStreamTask` method was being called.  This could cause transient failures as sometimes there may be more than one call to `createStreamTask` .  Also increased the time limit waiting for the rebalance to occur.

This PR generates documentation for all the Java clients (producer, consumer, connect, streams). It does not generate documentation for the broker metrics. I will look into broker documentation after this PR is completed.
Thanks for the PR, tests passed locally. LGTM, merged to trunk and 0.10.0 branches.
LGTM

`testPatternUnsubscription` failed in the PR build. It also failed in two trunk builds. @vahidhashemian, this seems to be happening more often since https://github.com/apache/kafka/commit/d7de59a579af5ba4ecb1aec8fed84054f8b86443 . Do we have a JIRA to investigate that?
LGTM provided that tests pass.
@ijuma could you please ask jenkins to retest this? The earlier build failure was on KStreams test timeouts and unrelated to this PR. thanks.

@ijuma Some builds fail on this method, and some other on `testPatternSubscription`, so we are not experiencing a consistent behavior. But I agree that these failures started after that commit. There is no JIRA opened for this specific issue but I see [a few](https://issues.apache.org/jira/issues/?filter=12334559&jql=project%20%3D%20KAFKA%20AND%20status%20%3D%20Open%20AND%20text%20~%20%22waitUntilTrue%22%20ORDER%20BY%20createdDate%20DESC) that seem to be failing where `waitUntilTrue` is involved. I can create another one for this one if you think it's needed.

@vahidhashemian, `waitUntilTrue` will generally be involved in any transient failure. However, if a particular change causes some tests to start failing semi-regularly, then we need to understand why that is so. If we have a satisfactory explanation that requires a longer timeout, then the particular test can pass the required timeout to `waitUntilTrue`.
@ijuma That sounds reasonable. I'll open a JIRA and start looking into it further.
LGTM. Merged to trunk. Thanks @bbejeck !

The Jenkins failures are due to other issues that we are working on right now.

Maybe we can keep using the default timeout 15 seconds for now? Or do you have any specific reasons to bump them up to 90 seconds?
@ijuma Simulating next jenkins build by minor correction to verify this PR. Last build masked by build failure caused by unrelated KStreams timeout issue.thanks
jenkins: retest this please, some unrelated zookeeper conn issue on unrelated test. thanks. cc @ijuma

The concurrent control in RocksDBStore / RocksWindowStore / MemoryLRUCache look good to me.

Two more things that we can probably do in parallel: while working on a small example leveraging this new API for querying the state stores, also consider writing the documentation sections for this new API (we will incorporate them into the new feature of queryable state store story later); and it'll be great if we can also do some benchmarks with / without the querying with your example code to illustrate the amount of overheads in terms of reduced throughput.

That being said, I think we do not need to make this PR perfect before merging it, though it still needs to wait for the KIP to be adopted. Maybe you can start the voting thread now as there are not too many questions in the discussion thread? After that and all current comments being addressed we can probably merge as is, and come back to revisit or even further change the APIs when we realize issues while writing the example code / docs.

I am now consistently seeing `kafka.api.PlaintextConsumerTest.testPatternUnsubscription` failure in all PRs that I am reviewing now. Does the commit potentially increase the round trips for metadata-refresh and follow-up subscription?
LGTM and merged to trunk.

I have been doing some more testing locally and I have even got the two tests (`testPatternSubscription` and `testPatternUnsubscription`) to fail with the wait time of 20 seconds (once in 10 or so runs). It seems in certain situations the metadata doesn't get updated and no matter how long the wait is it won't update. @guozhangwang I don't see, with the code change in the commit, if/how the metadata-refresh round-trip would be affected for following subscriptions.
jenkins: retest this please. current build error unrelated to this PR, same as #1559 cc @ijuma

The following check seems to have failed, and it is not related to the changes in the pull request. 

`kafka.api.PlaintextConsumerTest > testPatternUnsubscription FAILED
    java.lang.AssertionError: Expected partitions [topic-0, topic-1, tblablac-0, tblablac-1] but actually got []
        at org.junit.Assert.fail(Assert.java:88)
        at kafka.utils.TestUtils$.waitUntilTrue(TestUtils.scala:771)
        at kafka.api.PlaintextConsumerTest.testPatternUnsubscription(PlaintextConsumerTest.scala:288)
`

The check 'testPatternUnsubscription ' seems to have failed. It is unrelated to the pull request.  I have been able to run the tests locally successfully.  As per the suggestion in the following page, closing and reopening PR to restart the build: https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/KAFKA/Contributing+Code+Changes

Build still fails on this check: kafka.api.PlaintextConsumerTest > testPatternUnsubscription

It's unrelated to PR, and the check passes locally.  Might  be a transient kafka test error. Would retry building this in a day.

Starting the conversation with this pull request.  It seems to work well, and is minimally invasive to the code and command line tool API. I think this is a better approach than putting replication-factor changes in kafka-topics.sh --alter because the replication re-assignment is likely going to require a lot of partition copying, and it's probably better to review the effect rather than it being hidden.

I bumped the 'version' on the topics to move json file, but it turns out no one looks at the version number, anyway.  It's backwards compatible with version 1, and old code getting a version 2 file will just ignore the new fields.

I think that changing replication factor is probably something that ought to be done with a bit more transparency than what you get with the kafka-topics.sh command.  I've augmented kafka-reassign-partitions.sh to take an extra, optional 'replication-factor' param for each topic having partition reassignment.  You can review the proposed partition reassignment with the new replication factor applied before executing it. See #1596

@ijuma @guozhangwang I reverted part of the other commit and used a different fix. I could not reproduce the failures locally with this update. Not sure yet what made the previous code act inconsistently, but I thought this might get the builds pass, and I'll try to figure that out in the meantime.
@ewencp Thanks for the review. Updated the PR to address comments. PTAL.
It's unclear what that failed check is about.  I can't see how this change could have affected consumer pattern subscription.  I suspect fragile tests.
Looked at a few other recent pull requests.  Even documentation-only changes are causing the consumer tests to fail.  Looks like broken tests.

@harshach Thank you for the review.
Have moved KIP-60 to approved state and rebased this PR. Also added another unit test.
cc @ewencp @hachikuji
